content.description: Stick clip the first bolt. Make several hard moves to gain the slab. Head up moderate and varied climbing to the head wall. Weave your way through this technical crux. Finish by moving left to the anchor.
content.location: The bolted line to the right of the obvious right facing corner.

content.description: While this line may look to be about 5.6 at first glace it packs a little more punch that expected. I find it to be delightful but depending on your route finding choices it can become a very different route. Stick clip the first bolt unless the difficulty is inconsequential for you. Make a pretty textbook mantle move onto a foot ledge. Walk the ledge up to the kind high 2nd bolt (its very easy to get to). Then things get... thin. Take your time interpreting the sequence through the holds facing in all sorts of angles. You should pass just left of the roof if all goes well and you can then step out right onto the slab above and walk your proud lil self up the the anchor.
content.location: On the far right hand micro cliff at the Safe Space, this is the bolted line up the middle.

content.description: After climbing this route 3 times I still haven't done it 1st try of the day. The start is so technical and balancy it's just hard to put it all together right off the bat. After the tough start you get a few easy moves then another tough section and it keeps alternating between cruxes and cruises to the top. Great rock, fun movements and just good climbing the whole way. Don't be fooled. It looks 5.9 but... nope. Stick clip the 1st bolt.Named for the brand new static rope that was stolen off of the cliff when I had just taken it out of the package...
content.location: There are 2 routes with hard starts in the center of the middle face. This is the right hand one.

content.description: Could use a little more cleaning for sure but its a far cry better than it was on the first ascent when I had lichen salad between my fingers. Stick clip the first bolt of sunshine dust and climb up to it. Once on that nice foot ledge break left toward the crack perhaps getting a little committed before dropping your first good piece into the crack. Climb the crack with decent pro for the most part through some tensiony movement and interesting jams up to the anchor.
content.location: This is the crack on the left side of the farthest right had micro crag at the Safe Space.

content.description: There are two ways to climb this route that totally make sense. One is with finesse stemming pretty wide and using the crack for gear and occasionally advancement. Or you could just jam the wide crack like a beast. Nothin' too tricky about that. This goes to a tree on the left, but there is no anchor there right now. I'll get to it but it's also possible to top out or lower and retrieve your gear by way of Enchanted forest base area.
content.protection: Like two #3 and at least one #4 cam. I also placed a small tcu in a somewhat suspect flake before the tree.
content.location: The corner and left hand crack in this alcove.

climbs.name: On Wednesday we wear Pink Shorts
climbs.fa: Mike Zarnowski, Lee Hansche, and Torie Kidd summer 2021

content.description: A nice bit of thuggish climbing, because you know you want to. Due to the odd sized jams deep within and weird positions an ascent of this short crack will take much longer than you might think. As well this type of climbing really entertains all of your senses and when done well will also leave you smiling. When not done well, well you probably won't like this route very much haha!
content.protection: At least two #3 and one #4 a possible finger sized piece over the top where the angle lessens.

content.description: Stick clip then climb a nice little off width up to a chock stone where the second clip can be made from. After that's over a bit of lonesome dove style arete that leads to a bolted anchor.

climbs.name: The Man Who Sold the World

content.description:
Early in my own exploration of Russell I had climbed a ground up line on this section of cliff. In the process of sport development parts of this route were cleaned and bolted by other parties. Now kinda clean and mostly bolted I re-climbed this again recently and found it pretty darn fun still.

 Climb the hard start and first three bolts of "This is fine." then break left, possible cam placement, untill you can lean over left and start clipping bolts on "The Irresistible Edge" I couldn't resist either, finish up that route. You can lower off here, but originally I topped out.

 I never really settled on a name back then but climbing it again and clipping only bolts this felt appropriate.
content.protection: 6 bolts, possible cam, to lower off

content.description: Not a bad little warm up. Unfortunately a direct start to this would be ridiculously hard compared to the rest.  Start by stemming up the gully on the right hand side, its a bit scrappy but could clean up well. You quickly break left onto some delightful rock, which continues to the top. The cracky section toward the top is well worth a run up there.
content.location: On the right hand side of the center section there is a lil gully. Stem up the gully to start then break left onto the cleaner rock to follow the bolt line.

content.description: This is a nice little crack-ish climb with some really fun moves. It ends at the same tree as mixed feelings and can be top roped with a directional draw on that route. As with a lot of these schist cracks it's a good idea to work out your gear before leading unless of course you are comfortable fiddling with gear at this grade.

I really like routes that follow features. Corners, aretes, cracks roofs grooves etc. So I was immediately drawn to this line. It starts in a beautiful right facing corner, continues up a face and takes a sharp right to an arete (the irresistible edge itself). See I thought the climb was going to go up the face and out the roof, but the features and the rock quality thought otherwise. The face holds end and a path opens up heading right and up the edge. You'll have to lean out left to clip one of the bolts but it allows the rope to run well and protects well. Continue up trending a little left on lovely easier climbing to the top. Note: Scamper up to the stump at the base of the corner, stick clip the first bolt and then blast off. A fall before that first clip could be nasty and another bolt wouldn't keep you off the slab anywho.
content.location: At the center section of Safe Space look for an obvious right facing corner down low and an Irresistible arete above.

content.description: This crack/dyke feature is another fun little route with some interesting jams and other traditional type climbing. This route actually protects well with work but its very particular you might want to just TR this one.

There are a few sub-crags that make up this zone but it all makes sense as the Safe Space area. The whole spot just has a nice chill out of the way vibe and is a delightful place to get some pitches done. It also has a fair mix of trad and sport routes which is not common at Russell. On the left there is an older, and quite enjoyable bolted route and just to it's right, a really fun trad line called It Takes Two 5.8+. There are a couple more cracks over here that Mike Z put a lot of work into digging out and it was well worth the work.The central area of the crag is beautiful and proud with a variety of climbs up to 70-80 ft tall. The first climb done here that we know of was done ground up by Mike Z and Nick B they left so little trace we didn't realize they had ever climbed here. This was a bold lead through fragile, vegetated rock and required a cool head and a fair bit of chutzpah. The climbs here are 5.10s and 5.11s as well as a nice lil 5.7 on the right.The far right end has a couple of mini cliffs. A trad route and a sport route have been climbed here so far but I would expect more routes to be added over time.Most of the Safe Space routes were bolted with stick clips in mind. Plan to use one.
